covid.title: COVID-19
covid.title_header: The latest data on the pandemic in {{ state }}
covid.title_description1: Building on the Ministry of Health's previous COVIDNOW dashboard, this page provides a summarised view of the pandemic in Malaysia, allowing you to track its evolution on a weekly basis.
covid.donut1_tooltips: Includes utilisation for non-COVID-19 cases, in order to reflect the overall state of the public healthcare system
covid.donut2_tooltips: Includes utilisation for non-COVID-19 cases, in order to reflect the overall state of the public healthcare system
covid.donut3_tooltips: Includes utilisation for non-COVID-19 cases, in order to reflect the overall state of the public healthcare system
covid.diagram_header: What does the latest data show?
covid.area_chart_header: How are COVID-19 key indicators trending?
covid.table_header: A snapshot of the latest indicators
covid.bar_chart_header: How is vaccination influencing key epidemic indicators?
covid.bar_chart_cases1: Cases per 100k Population by Vaccination Status

vaccination.title: COVID-19 Vaccination
vaccination.title_header: The latest data on the National COVID-19 Immunisation Program
vaccination.title_description1: Building on the Ministry of Health's previous COVIDNOW dashboard, this page provides a summarised view of the COVID-19 vaccination program in Malaysia, allowing you to track its evolution on a daily basis.
vaccination.waffle_header: How vaccinated against COVID-19 are we?
vaccination.tooltips_dose1: Number of individuals who have received at least one dose of any vaccine
vaccination.tooltips_dose2: Number of individuals who received the second dose of a two-dose vaccine, or a single-dose vaccine (e.g. Cansino)
vaccination.combine_header: What is the current state of the COVID-19 vaccination program?
vaccination.area_chart_header: Daily vaccinations by dose and target group
vaccination.table_header: Which states are best vaccinated against COVID-19?

covidnow.title: DIGITALISATION
covidnow.title_header: COVIDNOW: Data from its year in the sun
covidnow.title_description: Over 6 million users, 44 million views, and 100 million clicks later, data on COVIDNOW - powered by Google Analytics - provides a large-sample insight into how users interact with a Malaysian-based data site. Beyond providing transparency on the usage of COVIDNOW, this dashboard also yields valuable insight into how Malaysians use the web - ranging from where usage is concentrated, to what times of day saw peak traffic, to the devices people use. We hope this helps everyone looking to do something similar.
covidnow.combine_header: COVIDNOW always received a steady stream of traffic, but saw huge spikes driven by shock value
covidnow.combine_description: The largest two spikes in traffic were due to the launch announcement (2 mil views over its first 2 days), and Malaysia hitting the '90% of adults fully vaccinated milestone' (2 mil views in a single day). The former was likely due to massive traction on social media, while the latter was due to 90% being used as the trigger to allow interstate travel.
covidnow.wmap_header: Globally, COVIDNOW was accessed from every country in the world, except Niger and North Korea
covidnow.wmap_description: We cannot determine if the views from a country are from locals or simply Malaysians living or visiting, but the site's consistent latency and speed across all regions was something we consistently monitored.
covidnow.mmap_header: Within Malaysia, views disproportionately came from the Klang Valley and urban centres
covidnow.mmap_description: This suggests that COVIDNOW may not have been the main source of information in rural areas versus traditional media, although this analysis is subject to the accuracy of aggregated location data from Google Analytics.
covidnow.heatmap_header: In general, users checked COVIDNOW when they woke up - likely due to updates being pushed overnight
covidnow.heatmap_description: Although this trend was likely driven by the timing of data updates, the data is consistent with conventional wisdom on user behaviour - people read the news and browse social media in the morning.
covidnow.heatmap_title: Median Views by Time of Day
covidnow.bar_header: For developers: A breakdown of views by key user demographics
covidnow.bar_description: While all these datapoints were useful to us in maintaining and optimising the site, the most important fact is that the vast majority of COVIDNOW's users accessed it from a mobile device. This is an important lesson - in the modern age, if your site is not mobile-friendly, you instantly lose a huge chunk of your traffic.

blood.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
blood.title_description: A stable and high supply of blood is critical for a well-functioning public healthcare system. This dashboard, which gives you near real-time updates on key indicators related to blood transfusion services, is brought to you by the National Blood Centre. The data is collected via the Blood Bank Information System v2 (BBISv2), a vein-to-vein blood-tracking system used by 22 main blood collection sites under MoH - and covers the majority of blood donations in Malaysia.
blood.table_header: Is {{ state }}'s current blood stock sufficient?
blood.area_tooltip: Tooltip for Blood supply over time
blood.combine_header: What are the latest blood donation trends in {{ state }}?
blood.combine_description: Blood compromises 3 main components - red blood cells, platelets, and plasma. Although plasma can be stored for up to 3 years, red blood cells can be only stored for up to 42 days, and platelets only for up to 5 days. Therefore, it is vital to maintain a high and stable level of blood donations; when blood donation activity is low or volatile, healthcare services that depend upon blood transfusions may be negatively affected.
blood.choro_header: How do blood donor rates differ across the country?
blood.choro_description: This data shows the % of the population aged 17-65 in each state which has donated at least once in the past year. The data for W.P. Kuala Lumpur may be higher than the true donor rate (and Selangor lower) due to data from the National Blood Centre's mobile campaigns around Selangor and W.P. Putrajaya being recorded as data for W.P. Kuala Lumpur.
blood.barmeter_header: A breakdown of donations by key variables
blood.barmeter1_title_tooltip: This data largely reflects the population prevalence of each blood type, rather than certain blood groups being more likely to donate.
blood.bar1_header: How strong is new donor recruitment in {{ state }}?
blood.bar1_description: Recruitment of new donors is vital to replace donors who reach their golden years and stop donating, as well as to support a growing population.
blood.heatmap_header: What proportion of the population in {{ state }} donates blood?
blood.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
blood.heatmap4_title: Donor retention: How well do we retain donors?
blood.map_description: The data is collected via the Blood Bank Information System v2 (BBISv2), a vein-to-vein blood-tracking system used by 22 main blood collection sites under MoH - and covers the majority of blood donations in Malaysia. There are several collection sites which have not yet been integrated into BBISv2.

healthcare.title: HEALTHCARE RESOURCES
healthcare.title_description: The Health Informatics Centre (PIK) maintains a constantly-updated database on all healthcare faciltiies in Malaysia. This dashboard documents the data in a manner that eases the process of finding a healthcare facility for your needs, and builds on the dataset to analyse healthcare access. The analysis on the access will be constantly enriched over time with data on private facilities, and other facility-specific indicators such as services offered and waiting times.
healthcare.map_header: How does access to healthcare facilities vary nationally?
healthcare.map_description1: Distance to the nearest healthcare facility is not the only measure of access to healthcare. There is a modern and growing body of research demonstrating the tough tradeoffs involved in localisation of healthcare - for instance, diversifying resources across multiple facilities in an area to decrease travel time, or concentrating them in a single hospital to up the quality of care.
healthcare.map_description2: The data presented here visually captures only one aspect of healthcare access (proximity), and is intended as a starting point for policymakers and the community to have a conversation about access.

bed.title: HEALTHCARE RESOURCES
bed.title_description: Hospital capacity utilisation is one of the most critical operational indicators monitored by the Ministry of Health. As a result of the Medical Development Division's pandemic work to increase reporting sophistication, hospital-level data on bed utilisation is now available in a timely manner. This dashboard presents that data transparently, and will be enriched over time with further data on utilisation and provision of hospital-specific services.
bed.choro_header: How does hospital bed utilisation vary nationally?
bed.timeseries_placeholder: Select a facility from the table above

peka.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
peka.title_description: PeKa B40 is a MoH initiative which aims to sustain the healthcare needs of low income groups by focusing on non-communicable diseases (NCDs). Recipients of the Bantuan Prihatin Rakyat (previously known as Bantuan Sara Hidup) and their spouses aged 40 and above are automatically eligible for free health screenings. This dashboard, which gives you near-real-time updates on PeKa B40 screenings, is brought to you by ProtectHealth Corporation.
peka.screening_header: What are the latest screening trends in {{ state }}?
peka.screening_description1: Health screening is vital to ensure early detection of non-communicable diseases.
peka.choro_header: How do screening rates differ across the country?
peka.choro_description: This data shows the % of the population eligible for PeKa B40 screening in each state which has been screened at least once.
peka.bar1_header: How strong is the new donor recruitment in {{ state }}?
peka.bar1_description: Recruitment of new donors is vital to replace donors who reach their golden years and stop donating, as well as to support a growing population.
peka.heatmap_header: What proportion of the eligible population in {{ state }} has been screened?
peka.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
peka.bar2_title1: Motivation: Why do people pledge to donate organs?

organ.title: HEALTHCARE PROGRAMS
organ.title_description: The National Transplant Resource Centre has conducted Organ Donor Pledge registrations since 1997. However, some of the data was collected and recorded manually. The data shown here reflects  records from 2009 which could be digitalised and consolidated with the new pledges collected via MySejahtera. MoH is committed to ensuring the delivery of comprehensive healthcare information to the rakyat.
organ.bar_header: What are the latest organ pledger trends in {{ state }}?
organ.bar_description1: On 6 September 2022, a digital Organ Donor Pledge was launched on MySejahtera. The recent spike in pledges is attributable to this digitalisation effort.
organ.table_header: Blood compromises 3 components - red blood cells, platelets, and plasma. Although plasma can be stored for up to 1 year, red blood cells can be only stored for up to 35 days, and plasma only for up to 5 days. Therefore, it is vital to maintain a high and stable level of blood donations when blood donation activity is low or volatile, healthcare services that depend upon blood transfusions may start to come under stress.
organ.choro_header: How do organ pledger rates differ across the country?
organ.choro_description: This data shows the % of the total population in each state which has pledged to donate their organs.
organ.bar1_header: How strong is new pledger recruitment in {{ state }}?
organ.bar1_description: To meet Malaysia's healthcare needs, it is vital to recruit as many new pledgers as possible.
organ.heatmap_header: What proportion of the population in {{ state }} donates blood?
organ.heatmap_description: To ensure a stable and high supply of blood, we need 10% of the eliglble population to donate at least 1 time per year.
organ.chart_header: Motivation: Why do people pledge to donate organs?
